forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Bloc holds its francophone base outside Montreal and maintains efficient vote splits, limiting CPC gains mainly to Quebec City and a handful of rural strongholds. Even if Liberals rebound or a new Liberal leader emerges, most of those gains come at the Bloc’s expense in and around Montreal rather than boosting the Conservatives, leaving the Bloc still ahead of CPC in Quebec seat count.
forecast.rationale: Baseline matters: in 2021 the Bloc beat the Conservatives in Quebec by 32–10 seats. Under first‑past‑the‑post, the Bloc’s vote is typically more efficiently distributed across francophone regions, whereas Conservative strength is concentrated in the Quebec City area and a limited set of ridings (Beauce/Chaudière‑Appalaches, Portneuf–Jacques‑Cartier, Louis‑Saint‑Laurent, etc.). Even with national Conservative momentum, translating Quebec‑wide vote share into two dozen seats is a high bar without a broad francophone shift. As of late 2024, public polling often showed CPC gains in Quebec, but not a consistent province‑wide dominance. Meanwhile, provincial dynamics (PQ resurgence, CAQ softness) tend to bolster sovereigntist sentiment and can stabilize Bloc support in many regions. Also, riding‑level frictions matter: candidate eligibility or nomination issues in key Quebec City ridings can cost the CPC marginal seats, as suggested by the reported case where a Conservative candidate couldn’t run and the Bloc benefitted. What could flip this? A pronounced and sustained CPC lead among francophone voters (not just in Quebec City), visible in reputable Quebec‑only polling; high‑profile CPC recruits in target Bloc ridings; or a Liberal leadership change (e.g., to a popular Quebec‑friendly leader) that drastically reshapes the field by splitting the Bloc vote while leaving CPC competitive in three‑way races. Why not higher than my estimate? Because CPC momentum and a potential Liberal leadership reset create real downside risk for the Bloc’s seat tally; in a three‑way contest, localized swings can flip many seats. Why not lower? Because the Bloc’s starting advantage, vote efficiency, and the limited universe of currently competitive CPC ridings make it more likely than not that the Bloc still finishes ahead of the Conservatives in Quebec seats absent a clear, sustained province‑wide realignment. I would update upward if: francophone‑only polling shows Bloc resilience (mid‑ to high‑20s or better) and CPC stalled outside Quebec City; Bloc lands strong local candidates/incumbent protections in key marginals. I would update downward if: CPC posts a consistent 5–10 point lead among francophones across multiple pollsters, secures star candidates in Bloc‑held ridings, or a new Liberal leader meaningfully reduces the Bloc’s floor without materially hurting CPC competitiveness.
